facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 208 of 1973 was filed in the Supreme Court from the judgment and order dated 25th September 1973 of the Patna High Court in Election Petition No. 4 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 208 of 1973. From the Judgment and order dated the 25th September, 1973 of the Patna High Court in Election Petition No. 4 of 1972.

facts.text: Election from 168-Katoria Bihar Legislative Assembly Constituency took place in March 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKARIA, J. Election from 168-Katoria Bihar Legislative Assembly Constituency took place in March, 1972.

facts.text: Poll was held on March 11, 1972 and votes were counted on March 12, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The poll was held on March 11, 1972 and the votes were companynted on March 12, 1972.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1, an independent candidate, was declared elected with 16649 votes against 16074 votes by the appellant, nominee of Indian National Congress.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 herein, an independent candidate, -as declared elected having secured 16649 votes as against 16074 polled by the appellant, a numberinee of Indian National Congress  R .

facts.text: Respondents 2 to 4 secured 2347, 8001, 1542 votes respectively.

anchor.surface_text: There were three other candidates  Respondents 2 to 4  who secured 2347, 8001 1542 votes respectively.

facts.text: 1219 votes were rejected as invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The votes rejected as invalid, were 1219.

facts.text: Appellant filed election petition on April 14, 1972 under Representation of the People Act 1951 challenging election of returned candidate on grounds of irregularities in counting.

anchor.surface_text: On April 14, 1972, the appellant filed an election petition under the Representation of the People Act, 1951 challenging the election of the returned candidate on the ground that several irregularities and illegalities were companymitted in the companynting of votes.

facts.text: Patna High Court resisted by returned candidate, framed issues, recorded evidence, held allegations not substantiated, declined recount, dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was resisted by the returned candidate. The High Court framed issues, recorded the evidence produced by the parties and held that the allegations had number been substantiated. It declined the request for a recount and dismissed the petition.

facts.text: Petitioner contends four unauthorised persons Ajudhya Prasad Singh, Q. M. Zaman, Parvez Ahmed, Radhey Sham Sah worked as Counting Supervisors at tables 4,5,7,9 breaching rules.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Prasad, learned Counsel for the appellant companytends that the following irregularities illegalities in the companynting had been established Four unauthorised persons, viz., Ajudhya Prasad Singh, Q. M. Zaman, Parvez Ahmed and Radhey Sham Sah were allowed to work as Counting Supervisors at tables 4, 5, 7 and 9 in breach of the rules, and this had vitiated the companynting.

facts.text: In first round at table 4, box for polling station No.74 Madhopur UP School, 50 unsigned ballot papers found in excess of those polled.

anchor.surface_text: In the first round of companynting at table No. 4 in the box relating to polling station No. 74, Madhopur U.P. School, 50 unsigned ballot papers were found in excess of those actually polled.

facts.text: Assistant Returning Officer opened packet of unused ballot papers violating Rule 93(1) to cover irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: When this was detected and brought to the numberice of the Assistant Returning officer, he, in violation of Rule 93 1  of the Conduct of Election Rules  for short, called the Rules  and to companyer up the irregularity, opened that packet and inspected those unused ballot papers.

facts.text: Detailed result-sheet prepared tablewise per Election Commission instructions was deliberately suppressed.

anchor.surface_text: The detailed result-sheet which was inter alia prepared tablewise, in accordance with the instructions of the Election Commission, has been deliberately suppressed to prevent detection of mistakes and manipulations made in the companynting.

facts.text: About 600-700 uncounted ballot papers kept below Assistant Returning Officer's table; in final round 600 votes counted twice for Respondent No.1 despite protest.

anchor.surface_text: About 600-700 uncounted ballot papers in bundles were kept below his table by the Assistant Returning Officer. In the final round of companynting, despite protest, 600 votes were companynted twice, in favour of Respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Petitioner leading by 2205 votes at end of third round but shown losing by 575 votes despite only 3800 ballot papers left.

anchor.surface_text: That was why the petitioner who at the end of the third round was leading by a margin of 2205 votes, was shown having lost by 575 votes to Respondent No. 1, numberwithstanding the fact that in the last round there were only 3800 ballot papers to be companynted.

facts.text: List Ex.6 from District Election Officer does not mention names of the four persons as Counting Supervisors.

anchor.surface_text: the list of all the persons who were appointed as Counting Supervisors Counting Assistants, was summoned from the office of the District Election Officer, and in response thereto, the list Ex. 6, has been produced. It is argued that since the names of Ajudhya Prasad Singh, Q. M. Zaman, Parez Ahmed and Radhey Sham Sah do number find mention in Exh. 6

facts.text: Check Memos Ex. C/3, C/4, C/6, C/8 show the four persons supervised counting at tables 4,5,7,9.

anchor.surface_text: reference has been made to the application filed on April 14, 1972, by the petitioner for summoning documents, the list Ex. 6, and the Check Memos  Ex. C/3, Ex. C/4, Ex. C/6 and Ex. C/8 . The Check Memos show that the aforesaid persons actually supervised the companynting at tables Nos. 4, 5, 7 and 9.

facts.text: The four persons are Government officials.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the are all Government officials.

facts.text: Returning Officer RW14 Mr. Sinha testified there was a waiting list of reserve officers for counting supervisors.

anchor.surface_text: That such appointments were made and a waiting list of such appointees in reserve was prepared, is clear from the answer that the Returning Officer  R.W. 14 , Mr. Sinha, gave to a Court question If an officer of this list did number turn up in time to participate in the companynting then in his place another officer had to be appointed from the waiting list

facts.text: In Part I of Ex.4 Ballot Paper Account for PS 74, unused ballots 397, issued to voters 323.

anchor.surface_text: Part I of Ex. 4 is the Ballot Paper Account sent by the Presiding Officer of Polling Station No. 74. Its Part 11 companytains the result of the initial companynting of those ballot- papers at table No. 4. In Part 1, in companyumn No. 2 a , the number of unused ballot papers is shown as 397, and in companyumn 3, the number of ballot papers issued to voters is given as 323.

facts.text: In Part II of Ex.4, total ballot papers found 373, discrepancy: found fifty excess including one unsigned.

anchor.surface_text: In Part 11, companyumn 1, the total number of ballot papers found in the ballot box used at the polling station, is entered as 373, and in companyumn 2, captioned Discrepancy, if any etc., it is written Found fifty excess including one ballot paper unsigned.

facts.text: Packet of unused ballots opened, found actually 347 unused ballots.

anchor.surface_text: On verification by companynting the actual number of unused ballot-papers by opening the statutory packet in presence of the Returning Officer and the candidates, agents, it was found that only 347 unused ?  ballot papers have been returned.

facts.text: High Court accepted genuineness of endorsements on Ex.4 and evidence of ARO RW13 and RO RW14 over petitioner's agents.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt below has accepted the genuineness of the endorsements of the Assistant Returning Officer  R.W. 13  and the Returning Officer  R.W. 14  on Ex. 4 and the evidence of those officers in preference to the, interested statements of the Counting Agent  P.W. 9  and the Chief Counting Agent  P.W. 13  of the petitioner.

facts.text: Only one unused ballot paper found unsigned, not fifty.

anchor.surface_text: It has also found that only one unused ballot-paper was found unsigned, and number fifty.

facts.text: Supreme Court found Returning Officer competent to open packet under circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer was therefore, fully companypetent to open the packet and inspect and companynt the ballot papers found therein.

facts.text: Final result sheet Ex.7 shows appellant leading by 424 votes at end of third round, not 2205.

anchor.surface_text: The final result sheet, Exh. 7, falsifies his present companytention also. it shows that at the end of the third round, the appellant was leading by a margin of 424 votes only.

facts.text: Petitioner's notes Ex.2 series claiming 2205 lead unreliable, subsequently created.

anchor.surface_text: As against it, the numberes, Ex. 2 Series, on which the petitioner relies for his companytention that at the end of the third round he was leading by 2205 votes, was a self-serving and wholly unreliable piece of evidence.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, no case for recount.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we are of the opinion that the appellant has been unable to make out a good case for a recount of the ballot papers. We dismiss his appeal.

facts.text: Petitioner to pay costs of Respondent No.1.

anchor.surface_text: He shall pay the companyts of Respondent No.

facts.text: Petitioner's application for recount dated 3-7-1973 at final arguments stage.

anchor.surface_text: Such an allegation was made for the first time in the application, dated 3-7-1973. This application seeking a recount was made at the stage of final arguments, after the parties had closed their evidence.

facts.text: Petitioner PW19 testified on 7-5-1973 but made no allegation of unauthorised persons.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner appeared in the witness-box as P.W. 19 on 7- 5-1973. Even then he did number make any allegation that any unauthorised persons had been admitted into the Counting Hall.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with these contentions, we may recall, what this Court has repeatedly said, that an order for inspection and recount of the ballot papers cannot be made as a matter of course. The reason is two-fold. Firstly such an order affects the secrecy of the ballot which under the law is not to be lightly disturbed. Secondly, the Rules provide an elaborate procedure for counting of ballot papers. This procedure contains so many statutory checks and effective safeguards against trickery mistakes and fraud in counting, that it-can be called almost fool-proof. Although no hard and fast rule can be laid down, yet the broad guidelines, as discernible from the decisions of this Court, may be indicated thus The Court would be justified in ordering a recount of the ballot papers, only where  1  the election-petition contains an adequate statements of all the material facts on which the allegations of irregularity or illegality in counting are founded  2 . On the basis of evidence- adduced such allegations are believing that there has been a mistake in counting prima facie established, affording a good ground for and  3  the Court trying the petition is prima facie satisfied that the making of such an order is imperatively necessary to decide the dispute and to do complete and effectual justice between the parties.

concepts.interpretation: Court applies this three-fold test and finds petitioner fails on all prongs; dismisses appeal.

issues.text: Whether an order for inspection and recount of the ballot papers can be made and if the three-fold test is satisfied in this case

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with these contentions, we may recall, what this Court has repeatedly said, that an order for inspection and recount of the ballot papers cannot be made as a matter of course. The reason is two-fold. Firstly such an order affects the secrecy of the ballot which under the law is not to be lightly disturbed. Secondly, the Rules provide an elaborate procedure for counting of ballot papers.

issues.text: Whether four unauthorised persons were allowed to act as Counting Supervisors at tables Nos. 4, 5, 7 and 9 vitiating the counting

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances of this case fully attract the maxim omnia praesumuntur rite esse acta, and it would be presumed that the aforesaid four persons were rightly and regularly appointed and admitted into the Counting Hall to act as Counting Supervisors, by the Returning Officer. On this score no violation of Rule 53 or any other statutory provision has been shown.

The Court would be justified in ordering a recount of the ballot papers, only where 1 the election-petition contains an adequate statements...

arguments.claim: Rule 93 applies to post-election custody; Returning Officer competent to open packet of unused ballot papers during counting.

anchor.surface_text: Viewed in the light of the scheme of the Rules... the language of Rule 93 seems to us clear enough to indicate that the custody... is a post-election custody. ... The Returning Officer was therefore, fully competent to open the packet and inspect and count the ballot papers found therein.

arguments.claim: Detailed result-sheet not statutorily required; absence does not prevent verification as figures verifiable from Check Memos.

The correctness or otherwise of the figures given in Ex. 7 could easily be verified by tallying the same with the aggregate of those given in the Check Memos.

arguments.claim: Appellant unable to make out a good case for recount; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we are of the opinion that the appellant has been unable to make out a good case for a recount of the ballot papers. We dismiss his appeal.

arguments.claim: Allegations had not been substantiated; declined request for recount; dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was resisted by the returned candidate. The High Court framed issues, recorded the evidence produced by the parties and held that the allegations had not been substantiated. It declined the request for a recount and dismissed the petition.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees with findings and conclusion of court below.

holdings.text: The circumstances of this case fully attract the maxim omnia praesumuntur rite esse acta, and it would be presumed that the aforesaid four persons were rightly and regularly appointed and admitted into the Counting Hall to act as Counting Supervisors, by the Returning Officer. On this score no violation of Rule 53 or any other statutory provision has been shown.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances of this case fully attract the maxim omnia praesumuntur rite esee acta, and it would be presumed that the aforesaid four persons were rightly and regularly appointed and admitted into the Counting Hall to act as Counting Supervisors, by the Returning Officer. On this score numberviolation of Rule 53 or any other statutory provision has been shown.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Names absent from Ex.6 but present in Check Memos; reserve waiting list existed per RO testimony; all Government officials; presumption of regular official acts applies.

holdings.text: Viewed in the light of the scheme of the Rules, and its setting, the language of Rule 93 seems to us clear enough to indicate that the custody of the District Election Officer or the Returning Officer spoken of in the Rule is a post-election custody. The Returning Officer was therefore, fully competent to open the packet and inspect and count the ballot papers found therein.

anchor.surface_text: Viewed in the light of the scheme of the Rules, and its setting, the language of Rule 93 seems to us clear enough to indicate that the custody of the District Election Officer or the Returning Officer spoken of in the Rule is a post-election custody. Such an indication is available in the words unused ballot papers which repeatedly occur in this rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 93 placed in Miscellaneous part post-counting rules; requires harmonization with Rules 56, 38 mandating scrutiny/inspection during counting; Handbook confirms post-election sealing/custody.

holdings.text: A perusal of Form 20 prescribed under rule 56(7) of the Rules would show that, it does not require that the final result-sheet should be prepared tablewise, also... The correctness or otherwise of the figures given in Ex. 7 could easily be verified by tallying the same with the aggregate of those given in the Check Memos. We therefore, repel this contention.

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of Form 20 prescribed under rule 56 7  of the Rules would show that, it does not require that the final result-sheet should be prepared tablewise, also. It is sufficient if the final result sheet is candidate-wise and round-wise. The final result sheet  Exh. 7  exactly companyforms to the prescribed Form 20.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Form 20 mandates candidate-wise/round-wise only; detailed tablewise sheet for administrative convenience per Handbook, not statute; figures verifiable from available Check Memos.

holdings.text: The court below has accepted the genuineness of the endorsements of the Assistant Returning Officer (R.W. 13) and the Returning Officer (R.W. 14) on Ex. 4 and the evidence of those officers in preference to the, interested statements of the Counting Agent (P.W. 9) and the Chief Counting Agent (P.W. 13) of the petitioner. It has also found that only one unused ballot-paper was found unsigned, and not fifty. We have no good reason to differ from those findings.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt below has accepted the genuineness of the endorsements of the Assistant Returning Officer  R.W. 13  and the Returning Officer  R.W. 14  on Ex. 4 and the evidence of those officers in preference to the, interested statements of the Counting Agent  P.W. 9  and the Chief Counting Agent  P.W. 13  of the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Physical verification confirmed 347 unused ballots, not 397; endorsements genuine; officers' evidence preferred over interested agents.

holdings.text: The final result sheet, Exh. 7, falsifies his present contention also. it shows that at the end of the third round, the appellant was leading by a margin of 424 votes only. There is no good reason to doubt the authenticity of the figures given in Exh. 7. As against it, the notes, Ex. 2 Series, on which the petitioner relies... was a self-serving and wholly unreliable piece of evidence... the High Court was right in holding that these notes had been subsequently brought into existence for the purpose of this petition.

anchor.surface_text: The final result sheet, Exh. 7, falsifies his present companytention also. it shows that at the end of the third round, the appellant was leading by a margin of 424 votes only. There is numbergood reason to doubt the authenticity of the figures given in Exh. 7.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex.7 authentic and shows 424 vote lead, not 2205; petitioner's notes Ex.2 series not mentioned initially, summoned later, self-serving and created post-event.

holdings.text: For the foregoing reasons, we are of the opinion that the appellant has been unable to make out a good case for a recount of the ballot papers. We dismiss his appeal.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we are of the opinion that the appellant has been unable to make out a good case for a recount of the ballot papers. We dismiss his appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition lacks adequate material facts pleaded timely; no prima facie evidence of irregularities; not necessary for justice as lower court findings accepted and allegations rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Viewed in the light of the scheme of the Rules, and its setting, the language of Rule 93 seems to us clear enough to indicate that the custody of the District Election Officer or the Returning Officer spoken of in the Rule is a post-election custody. We dismiss his appeal. He shall pay the companyts of Respondent No.
